rev.comment: Given the scale of the overall controversy about violence, the holding account issue seems out of place. restored it to chronology

Line 154: Line 154:
On November 3, a driver of a Mercedes who had a green light struck two protestors who were in the street blocking traffic. The two protestors were taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The driver was questioned by BART police and released, angering protesters who witnessed the events and called for the driver's arrest. <ref>{{cite news|last=Kuruvila|first=Matthai|title=Mercedes hits 2 Occupy Oakland protesters|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/BA5G1LQ06S.DTL|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
On November 3, a driver of a Mercedes who had a green light struck two protestors who were in the street blocking traffic. The two protestors were taken to the hospital with minor injuries. The driver was questioned by BART police and released, angering protesters who witnessed the events and called for the driver's arrest. <ref>{{cite news|last=Kuruvila|first=Matthai|title=Mercedes hits 2 Occupy Oakland protesters|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/03/BA5G1LQ06S.DTL|accessdate=November 6, 2011|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 3, 2011}}</ref>
â
===$20,000 deposit into Wells Fargo===
+
â
On November 7, Occupy Oakland accepted a $20,000 donation for urgent medical and legal expenses from Occupy Wall Street. The money was deposited into an Occupy Oakland lawyer's Wells Fargo bank account. The Occupy Oakland general assembly approved the decision to hold the money temporarily in a Wells Fargo account to be used immediately for bailing out jailed protesters. When the group's status as an unincorporated association is approved, the money will be transferred to a local credit union. This deposit was seen by some news outlets and Occupy Oakland participants as hypocritical because just a few days earlier, Occupy Oakland had protested against Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo spokesman Ruben Pulido said that this deposit "demonstrates that even Occupy Oakland understands â firsthand â the value and service that Wells Fargo provides its customers. Wells Fargo welcomes the 100 percent of Americans to allow us to help them meet their financial needs."<ref>[http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/2011/11/occupy-oakland-makes-20k-deposit-wells-fargo Occupy Oakland makes $20K deposit at Wells Fargo], San Francisco Examiner, November 8, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.occupyoakland.org/generalassembly/committees/ Occupy Oakland General Assembly statement on $20,000 donation]</ref><ref>[http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/09/occupy-oakland-protesters-deposit-funds-at-wells-fargo-after-bank-attacks/ Occupy Oakland Protesters Deposit Funds At Wells Fargo After Bank Attacks], CBS News, November 9, 2011</ref>
 
==Chronology of events==
==Chronology of events==
Line 344: Line 344:
===Week 5 (November 7 â November 13)===
===Week 5 (November 7 â November 13)===
  +
On November 7, Occupy Oakland accepted a $20,000 donation for urgent medical and legal expenses from Occupy Wall Street. The money was deposited into an Occupy Oakland lawyer's Wells Fargo bank account. The Occupy Oakland general assembly approved the decision to hold the money temporarily in a Wells Fargo account to be used immediately for bailing out jailed protesters. When the group's status as an unincorporated association is approved, the money will be transferred to a local credit union. This deposit was seen by some news outlets and Occupy Oakland participants as hypocritical because just a few days earlier, Occupy Oakland had protested against Wells Fargo. Wells Fargo spokesman Ruben Pulido said that this deposit "demonstrates that even Occupy Oakland understands â firsthand â the value and service that Wells Fargo provides its customers. Wells Fargo welcomes the 100 percent of Americans to allow us to help them meet their financial needs."<ref>[http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/2011/11/occupy-oakland-makes-20k-deposit-wells-fargo Occupy Oakland makes $20K deposit at Wells Fargo], San Francisco Examiner, November 8, 2011</ref><ref>[http://www.occupyoakland.org/generalassembly/committees/ Occupy Oakland General Assembly statement on $20,000 donation]</ref><ref>[http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2011/11/09/occupy-oakland-protesters-deposit-funds-at-wells-fargo-after-bank-attacks/ Occupy Oakland Protesters Deposit Funds At Wells Fargo After Bank Attacks], CBS News, November 9, 2011</ref>
  +
On November 9, five members of the Oakland City Council, Desley Brooks, Ignacio De La Fuente, Pat Kernighan, Libby Schaaf, Larry Reid, and an accompanying group of two dozen clergy and Oakland small business owners, held a press conference near [[Children's Fairyland]], calling for the immediate eviction of Occupy Oakland. The group alleged that the ongoing protest had harmed the economy of downtown Oakland, and cited reports of fire hazards in the camp. Upon learning of the conference, Occupy protesters interrupted Larry Reid's speech with chants, including "we are the 99 percent of Oakland." The council members and business owners than begin counter chanting "Occupy Oakland must go." Brooks, who had previously supported the protest, criticized the protesters for obstruction of the council's freedom of speech, saying, "This display was indicative of the problem with Occupy Oakland." A protester countered, "We cannot have dialogue when their statement is immediate eviction."<ref>Kuruvila, Matthai [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/09/BAH61LSRPF.DTL Occupy protesters shout down Oakland council] ''San Francisco Chronicle'' November 9, 2011</ref>
On November 9, five members of the Oakland City Council, Desley Brooks, Ignacio De La Fuente, Pat Kernighan, Libby Schaaf, Larry Reid, and an accompanying group of two dozen clergy and Oakland small business owners, held a press conference near [[Children's Fairyland]], calling for the immediate eviction of Occupy Oakland. The group alleged that the ongoing protest had harmed the economy of downtown Oakland, and cited reports of fire hazards in the camp. Upon learning of the conference, Occupy protesters interrupted Larry Reid's speech with chants, including "we are the 99 percent of Oakland." The council members and business owners than begin counter chanting "Occupy Oakland must go." Brooks, who had previously supported the protest, criticized the protesters for obstruction of the council's freedom of speech, saying, "This display was indicative of the problem with Occupy Oakland." A protester countered, "We cannot have dialogue when their statement is immediate eviction."<ref>Kuruvila, Matthai [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2011/11/09/BAH61LSRPF.DTL Occupy protesters shout down Oakland council] ''San Francisco Chronicle'' November 9, 2011</ref>
Line 352: Line 354:
| video1= [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buovLQ9qyWQ Police clash with students at UC Berkeley], Nov 9
| video1= [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=buovLQ9qyWQ Police clash with students at UC Berkeley], Nov 9
}} Oakland General Assembly had previously passed a statement of solidarity with the OccupyCal protest at the University of California Berkeley. In the evening of November 9, law enforcement from Oakland Police, Alameda County Sheriff, and UC Police unsuccessfully attempted to evict the members of OccupyCal from their encampment on the campus. Several students and at least one professor were arrested. In line with the earlier general assembly vote, members of Occupy Oakland joined in the Berkeley protest.
}} Oakland General Assembly had previously passed a statement of solidarity with the OccupyCal protest at the University of California Berkeley. In the evening of November 9, law enforcement from Oakland Police, Alameda County Sheriff, and UC Police unsuccessfully attempted to evict the members of OccupyCal from their encampment on the campus. Several students and at least one professor were arrested. In line with the earlier general assembly vote, members of Occupy Oakland joined in the Berkeley protest.
  +   +
After police had removed the tents from the encampment, protestors held a general assembly. It voted 569-31 in favor of a educational General Strike to be held state-wide on Tuesday November 15, 2011.
After police had removed the tents from the encampment, protestors held a general assembly. It voted 569-31 in favor of a educational General Strike to be held state-wide on Tuesday November 15, 2011.
